newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Stork quits Fokker restart talks.
newsitem.headline: Stork quits Fokker restart talks.

text.p: Engineering and industrial services group Stork NV said on Monday it was no longer bound to a memorandum of understanding on an attempted restart of bankrupt aircraft maker Fokker.
"The Fokker administrators have now concluded that any chance of a restart seems definitively off the cards," Stork said in a statement.

In March, the Fokker administrators said they, the Dutch state, Stork and industrial investment group Deleye Investment had agreed on a common approach for negotiations with the Malaysian government on a relaunch of Fokker.
Stork said Malaysia's state investment group Khazanah Nasional Berhad was not willing to shoulder its obligations together with the Dutch partners before a due diligence was fully completed.
It added that the Dutch government and Deleye Investment had not formally reacted to this and wanted to study the present situation first.
But Stork said the Fokker administrators and its management team thought the minimal infrastructure which Fokker needs for a successful restart was no longer there.
Fokker has almost completed building its last three aircraft and many of its remaining employees have left in the past weeks, it added.
Earlier today, a Stork spokesman said there were problems of a financial nature in the relaunch negotiations but he said media reports Stork had pulled out of the talks were premature.
Fokker went bankrupt last year when German majority shareholder Daimler Benz cut the company's financial lifeline, saying it could no longer bear the firm's huge losses.
The "Malaysian solution" was seen as the last chance of a rebirth of the Netherlands' only aviation group.
